adverbs.description: literally (comparative more literally, superlative most literally)

entries.meaning: Word for word; not figuratively; not as an idiom or metaphor.
examples: Synonyms: actually, really, unfiguratively, unmetaphorically; see also Thesaurus:actually
When I saw on the news that there would be no school tomorrow because of the snowstorm, I literally jumped for joy, and hit my head on the ceiling fan.

entries.meaning: (degree, figuratively, proscribed, contranym) Used non-literally as an intensifier for figurative statements: virtually, so to speak (often considered incorrect; see usage notes)
examples: He was so surprised, he literally jumped twenty feet in the air.
My daughter's pet rabbit had babies, and now we've literally got rabbits coming out of our ears.
On 9/11 people were literally glued to their TV sets.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Used to intensify or dramatize non-figurative statements.
examples: I had no idea, so I was literally guessing.
I was literally having breakfast when she arrived.
She was literally like, "What?", and I was literally like, "Yeah".

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Used as a generic downtoner: just, merely.
examples: It's not even hard⁠ to make—you literally just put it in the microwave for five minutes and it's done.
It won't take me long to get back, cause the store's literally two blocks away.
